name: Abkhaz
CAUSATIVE-FORM: r- (after other prefixes but immediately before root)

name: Batak (Karo)
NOTES: Has another causative prefix pe(r)- and -i.

name: Cahuilla
BASE-RESTRICTIONS-CAUS: none reported; examples use only intransitive bases

name: Chamorro
BASE-RESTRICTIONS-CAUS: none reported (this may be a voice, since the grammar calls it a "focus")
NOTES: These might be voices, but it doesn't matter since there's zero chance of syncretism anyway.

name: Chukchi
NOTES: Review Dunn 1999 to fill in details.

name: Epena Pedee
NOTES: Instrumental form's "h" should be superscriped. Thanks, Sheets.

name: Grebo
NOTES: Extremely obvious syncretism, classified as just one affix. Both meanings can be obtained with same affix (see p. 33, 56)

name: Hausa
NOTES: Applicative can also be locative-ish; -aC is claimed to be one morpheme, though it can appear as -as, -ar, -an, or -am; the distinction isn't sensitive to whether it's causative or benefactive.

name: Ika
CAUSATIVE-FORM: -s, a second strategy claimed to be resyllabification

name: Jakaltek
NOTES: I can't find the applicative, but that doesn't seem to matter since the causatives are periphrastic, contra WALS.

name: Khoekhoe
NOTES: True causative is periphrastic; the morphological causative is more properly factitive.

name: Kanuri
CAUSATIVE-FORM: -t- (infixed to base), yìtə̀- (prefixed to "applied form"), possibly also yìkkə̀-
BASE-RESTRICTIONS-CAUS: Hutchison says only few instances, possibly none productive
NOTES: Applicative is the base for some (non-productive?) causatives and an itself be interpreted causatively.

name: Koyraboro Senni
NOTES: ha/ka (separate word) and suffix -nda (not used together) can be ambiguous between comit/inst sense and causative

name: Kutenai
NOTES: Source is almost unreadble, it's structured so badly.

name: Malagasy
NOTES: Polinsky (2005) analyzes Malagasy as having an applicative, but it is appears to be circumstantial voice

name: Maricopa
BASE-RESTRICTIONS-CAUS: mostly intrans. -y suffix (with a prefix) can causativize only a few transitives
BASE-RESTRICTIONS-APPL: benefactive: lexically restricted? others: noun base (case marking)
NOTES: Possible, but unclear because suffix doesn't seem very productive; causative requires additional prefix in ben applicative

name: Meithei
BASE-RESTRICTIONS-CAUS: none; in-, mono-, and ditransitives all possible

name: Nez Perce
BASE-RESTRICTIONS-CAUS: none explicit; examples use only intransitive

name: Nahuatl (Tetelcingo)
BASE-RESTRICTIONS-CAUS: mostly intransitive, some transitives; with -liya only on intransitive
NOTES: “They include -a 'transitive', -(y)a 'transitive, imperfective present', -liya 'applicative', -tiya 'causative', -ltiya 'causative', -wiya 'applicative', -lwiya 'applicative', -owa 'verberalizer, loan nativizer'. -tiya can be used as a verbalizer, like husband-tiya 'to marry s.o.'

name: Nunggubuyu
BASE-RESTRICTIONS-CAUS: none for causative; factitive attaches to adjectival nouns

name: Oneida
BASE-RESTRICTIONS-CAUS: the relevant one attaches only to intransitives
NOTES: Obvious enough that even the 60+-year-old grammar points out the syncretism (pp. 78-80)

name: Paiwan
NOTES: Applicatives are most likely voice markers.

name: Passamaquoddy-Maliseet
CAUSATIVE-FORM: Use of verb "cause;" requires applicative morphology to indicate causee.

name: Shipibo-Konibo
NOTES: not really caus-instr syncretism, but may have restricted caus. sense

name: Squamish
CAUSATIVE-FORM: -s (caus., can be used as applic.), -mi/-ni (applic. used as caus.)
NOTES: Most applicatives for this language are lumped together under the broad label "relational" and can be used as causatives; the causative suffix can be used as an applicative; dissertation p. 232 contains a mislabeled example, where the so-called causative actually isn't. Relational also marks SOURCE; redirective can be SOURCE, BENEFACTIVE, DATIVE, or POSSESSOR

name: Tagalog
CAUSATIVE-FORM: i-, ika-, i(ka)pag-, i(ka)-pang- (depends on voice)
NOTES: Tricky; the i- shows up in several places, but it's one of several variants (replaces -um-), and in the case of instrumentals, the base is entirely different.

name: Usan
BASE-RESTRICTIONS-CAUS: none; need not be a verb

name: Wambaya
BASE-RESTRICTIONS-CAUS: possibly intransitive only; factitive from adjectives
NOTES: Locative can also have a sense of "away from"
